misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different program instead of the specified grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a distance-between-points calculator using coordinates and Math.sqrt instead of a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade (0–100) and prints a corresponding letter grade using conditional ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this question by computing the distance between two points read from the user.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: This task requires a program that reads a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and uses conditional logic to map that grade into the correct letter grade (A–F) according to the provided ranges, then prints the letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value
No conditional (if/else) logic on grade ranges exists in the code
Output reports a distance, not a letter grade
The required letter grade mapping (A–F) is never computed or printed
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different homework problems or reuse of an earlier distance-formula example instead of implementing the specified grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the current logic with code that: (1) reads a single numeric grade from the user, (2) uses an if/else-if/else chain (or switch on ranges) to check which interval the grade falls into (90–100, 80–89, etc.), and (3) prints the corresponding letter grade as shown in the sample run.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is structured around computing a geometric distance and contains no references to grades, ranges, or letter outputs, which clearly conflicts with the problem specification.

evidence.note: All logic is devoted to reading coordinate pairs and computing a distance; there is no reading of a single grade, no conditional checks on grade ranges, and no letter grade output as required.

misconceptions.name: Implemented solution for incorrect problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating the distance between two points, instead of the required Grade Calculator program (Q3). None of the assignment tasks (reading a single grade, using conditional logic for grades A-F) were implemented.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted the answer to a different assignment question (e.g., Q1 or Q2) for Q3.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must prompt for and read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: Code prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 coordinates.
Code uses Math.sqrt to calculate distance.
Output reports 'The distance of the two points is ' + distance.
No grade calculation or conditional logic for grades (A, B, C, D, F) is present.
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission of the wrong file or failure to attempt the assigned question (Q3).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment instructions for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and ensure you submit the correct file implementing the required grading logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code is clearly and fully dedicated to solving the distance formula problem, which confirms it is answering the wrong question for Q3.

evidence.note: The core logic calculates the distance between two points, not a student grade.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The output confirms the program's purpose is distance calculation, not grade assignment.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Solved - Task Mismatch
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different problem (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator problem specified in Q3.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code from a different assignment or problem set, possibly confusing which problem they were supposed to solve.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student should have written a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on the provided scale.
symptoms: Code reads two coordinate pairs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade
Code calculates distance between points using the distance formula instead of determining letter grades
Program output shows 'The distance of the two points is...' instead of 'Letter grade: X'
No conditional logic for grade ranges (90-100, 80-89, etc.)
No use of if/else statements for grade classification
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either misread the problem statement, submitted the wrong file, or confused this problem with a different programming exercise.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read problem Q3 carefully. You need to: (1) read ONE numeric grade value, (2) use if/else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) print the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence - the submitted code solves a fundamentally different problem (distance calculation) rather than the grade calculator problem (Q3). This is not a logical error but a complete task mismatch.

evidence.note: Student reads four coordinate values instead of one grade value as required by Q3

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(sum_of_squares);
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Program calculates and displays distance between points, not letter grades
Code implements distance formula mathematics instead of grade classification logic

misconceptions.name: Reads coordinates instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: Instead of reading a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, the program reads four double values representing two points (x1, y1, x2, y2). This does not match the problem requirement of reading one grade value.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the program should read two coordinate points (x1, y1, x2, y2) from the user as input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for and read a single numeric grade (0–100), typically into one variable such as `int grade = input.nextInt();` or `double grade = input.nextDouble();` after printing `Enter grade:`.
symptoms: The prompts ask for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a grade.
Multiple `nextDouble()` calls are used to read four values instead of a single grade input.
No variable representing a grade is declared or read.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this task and a distance-between-points example, leading to reusing that pattern instead of mapping the stated problem to its required input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Redesign the input section so that you declare a single variable for the grade and read exactly one numeric value from the user with a prompt like `Enter grade:`.
related_concepts: Mapping problem description to program inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code unambiguously reads four doubles labeled as coordinates and never references a grade variable.

evidence.note: The program reads four coordinate values instead of a single numeric grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional logic for grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program does not contain any conditional statements to test the numeric grade against the required ranges for letter grades (A–F). As a result, no grade ranges (including A and B) are implemented at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that computing the distance between two points is the entire task and does not think to implement any if/else conditions for grading.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The solution should use conditional logic (e.g., an if–else-if chain) that checks the numeric grade against specified ranges (90–100 for A, 80–89 for B, etc.) and selects the corresponding letter.
symptoms: No `if`, `else if`, `else`, or `switch` statements exist in the program.
No variable stores a grade to be compared against thresholds.
The control flow is purely sequential: read input, compute distance, print result.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to translate the grading rules into conditional logic, likely due to solving a different example problem (distance formula) instead of the required grade calculation.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a grade variable and an if–else-if chain that checks the grade against the ranges 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, and below 60 to determine the correct letter.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code has no conditional constructs at all, so it cannot possibly implement the grade ranges.

evidence.note: The entire main method has no conditional statements, so no grade ranges (including A and B) are checked.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Outputs distance instead of letter grade
misconceptions.description: The program prints a numeric distance between two points with a message about distance, rather than printing a letter grade (A–F) based on a numeric grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the required output is the distance between two points, formatted as a numeric value, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should output a letter grade corresponding to the input numeric grade, using a message like `Letter grade: B` for an input of 85.
symptoms: Output message is "The distance of the two points is ...".
The program never prints a letter such as A, B, C, D, or F.
No variables or strings are used to represent or output a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion of this assignment with a distance-calculation example, leading to implementation and output that solve a different problem than specified.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the distance computation and message with logic that determines the correct letter (A–F) from the numeric grade and prints it in the required format, e.g., `System.out.println("Letter grade: " + letter);`.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categorical outputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only output is clearly about distance; there is no trace of a letter grade in the code.

evidence.snippet:
// display the result to the user
        System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The program prints a distance message and numeric value, not a letter grade.
